title: Dizzy Nutter
text:
Everett Clarence "Dizzy" Nutter (August 27, 1893July 25, 1958) was a former professional baseball player. In an eight-year career, Nutter played in one <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">major league</a> season with the <a href="Boston%20Braves%20%28baseball%29">Boston Braves</a> in 1919. He was listed as in height and weighed .
Biography.
Early life.
Nutter was born "Everett Clarence Nutter" on August 27, 1893, in <a href="Roseville%2C%20Ohio">Roseville, Ohio</a>.
Career.
In 1914, Nutter began his professional baseball career playing for the D-level <a href="Charleston%20Senators">Charleston Senators</a> of the <a href="Ohio%20State%20League">Ohio State League</a>. During the 1914 season, Nutter recorded a .271 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> with 108 <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> and seven <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a>. He continued his minor-league career in 1915 with Charleston before joining the B-level <a href="New%20Haven%20Murlins">New Haven Murlins</a> in 1916. Nutter played in New Haven for two years before his contract was purchased by the Boston Braves on August 29, 1919. He made his major league debut for the Boston Braves on September 7, 1919, in a game against the <a href="History%20of%20the%20New%20York%20Giants%20%28NL%29">New York Giants</a>, playing played <a href="center%20fielder">center field</a> and recording two hits in four <a href="plate%20appearance">plate appearance</a>s.
After playing eighteen games for the Braves during which he batted .212, Nutter returned to New Haven for the remainder of the 1919 season. For the <a href="New%20Haven%20Weissmen">New Haven Weissmen</a>, he led the team in hits, <a href="double%20%28baseball%29">doubles</a>, and <a href="triple%20%28baseball%29">triples</a> during the 1919 and 1920 seasons. Nutter's last season of professional baseball was in 1922 for New Haven Weissmen.
After baseball.
Nutter died on July 25, 1958, in <a href="Battle%20Creek%2C%20Michigan">Battle Creek, Michigan</a>, and was buried in <a href="Rose%20Hill%20Cemetery%20%28Ohio%29">Rose Hill Cemetery</a> in Roseville, Ohio.
